newsitem.title: USA: Consumer group seeks to cancel utility bond plans. [CORRECTED 17:51 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Consumer group seeks to cancel utility bond plans. [CORRECTED 17:51 GMT]

text.p: A coalition of consumer groups announced Tuesday a push to organize public opposition to state-approved plans by California's investor-owned utilities to issue up to $9 billion (corrects from $9 million) of "stranded cost" bonds this year.

The bonds are part of the state's effort to deregulate its electricity industry, while guaranteeing residential and small commerical ratepayers a 10 percent rate cut and allowing utilities to recover previous investments.
Starting in January, California will allow consumers to choose their power supplier, although large industrial users are expected to be the main beneficiaries of the change.

"Californians against Utility Taxes" (CUT), which includes consumer advocate Ralph Nader, said Tuesday the rate cut for small customers amounts to less than two percent after the financing costs for the new bonds are included.
The group also said the plan shifts the cost of nuclear and other uneconomic investments back to consumers.

"Instead of ensuring that California's artificially inflated rates dropped to market levels under deregulation, this new law keeps utility rates 50 percent higher than the national average for five years," said consumer advocate Harvey Rosenfield.

PG&E Corp's Pacific Gas & Electric Co and Edison International's Southern California Edison Co are expected to issue the first tranche of bonds later this year. The utilities are seeking to issue up to $28.5 billion of the securities, but regulators have final say over the amount.
